title: 2022 Russian Invasion of Ukraine
summary: Russia launched a full-scale military invasion of Ukraine on February 24, 2022, following months of military buildup along Ukraine's borders. The invasion marked the largest military conflict in Europe since World War II.

russian_perspective.official_narrative: Russia characterizes the invasion as a 'special military operation' necessary to demilitarize and denazify Ukraine, protect Russian-speaking populations in Donbas, and prevent NATO expansion eastward. Moscow claims it acted defensively in response to Western aggression and Ukrainian persecution of ethnic Russians.

media_framing.terminology: Never called a 'war' or 'invasion' - consistently termed 'special military operation' (spetsoperatsiya)
justifications: Protection of Donbas civilians from 'Ukrainian genocide'
Preventing Ukraine from developing nuclear weapons
Eliminating neo-Nazi elements in Ukrainian government
media_framing.prohibited_narratives: Russian law criminalizes calling it a 'war' or spreading 'false information' about Russian military actions

key_quotes.speaker: Vladimir Putin
key_quotes.quote: I have made the decision of a military operation... Its purpose is to protect people who have been subjected to bullying and genocide... for which we will strive for the demilitarization and denazification of Ukraine.

key_quotes.speaker: Sergey Lavrov (Foreign Minister)
key_quotes.quote: We did not invade Ukraine. We declared a special military operation because we had absolutely no other way of explaining to the West that dragging Ukraine into NATO was a criminal act.

russian_perspective.evolution: Initial narrative focused on quick 'denazification.' After military setbacks, shifted to protecting Donbas, preventing NATO expansion, and resisting Western imperialism. By 2023-2024, framed as existential conflict between Russia and collective West.

western_perspective.official_narrative: Unprovoked act of aggression violating international law and Ukraine's sovereignty. Represents Russian imperial ambitions and attempt to restore Soviet sphere of influence.

focus_areas: Russian war crimes and civilian casualties

key_responses: Military aid to Ukraine ($100+ billion from US alone)
International Criminal Court arrest warrant for Putin

us_perspective.official_position: Clearest violation of international law since WWII. US leads coalition supporting Ukraine with weapons, intelligence, and financial aid while avoiding direct military confrontation with Russia. Framed as defense of rules-based international order and democracy against authoritarianism.
key_actions: $75+ billion in military, humanitarian, and financial aid (as of 2024)
HIMARS, Patriot missiles, Abrams tanks, F-16 training
us_perspective.political_divisions: Broad bipartisan support initially, but growing Republican skepticism about aid levels. Progressive left questions escalation risks. Debate over red lines and ATACMS restrictions.

eu_perspective.official_position: Existential threat to European security order. EU unity on sanctions and support for Ukraine, though energy dependence on Russia complicated response. Represents test of European ability to act independently on security.
key_actions: Candidate status for Ukraine EU membership
eu_perspective.internal_divisions: Hungary (Orbán) opposes some sanctions and aid. Poland and Baltics most hawkish. Germany initially hesitant (Scholz's 'Zeitenwende' speech marked shift). France seeks diplomatic off-ramps while supporting Ukraine.
concerns: Energy crisis from Russian gas cutoff

chinese_perspective.official_position: Neutral but tilts toward Russia. Opposes NATO expansion and Western hegemony, but officially respects Ukrainian sovereignty. Refuses to condemn Russia or call it invasion. Promotes diplomatic solution while deepening Russia economic ties.
key_statements: Xi Jinping: 'No limits' partnership with Russia (Feb 2022)
Abstained on UN votes condemning Russia
actions: Increased trade with Russia ($200+ billion in 2023)
No military aid to Russia (under US pressure)
motivations: Strategic partnership with Russia against US

indian_perspective.official_position: Strategic autonomy - refuses to pick sides. Maintains historical ties with Russia (defense equipment, energy) while deepening US partnership. Abstained on UN votes. Focuses on national interest over ideology.
key_actions: Abstained on all UN votes condemning Russia
Massively increased Russian oil imports (became top buyer)
Expanded Quad cooperation with US, Japan, Australia
Hosted peace talks, Modi urged Putin 'not era of war'
rationale: 70% of Indian military equipment is Russian
Cheap Russian energy benefits Indian economy
China threat makes Russia relationship valuable
indian_perspective.internal_debate: Government position widely supported. Some progressives advocate stronger stand on principle. Business community supports pragmatic approach.

global_south_perspective.positions_vary: Significant portion abstained on UN votes. Many resent being pressured to pick sides. Focus on impact of conflict on food/energy prices rather than geopolitics.

major_views.africa: Many abstained. Some remember Russian support during decolonization. Concerned about food security (Ukraine/Russia are major grain exporters). Wagner presence complicates relations.
major_views.middle_east: Divided - Gulf states try to maintain ties with both. Turkey plays mediator role. Iran supports Russia. Most focus on energy markets and avoiding taking sides.
major_views.latin_america: Mostly condemned invasion but oppose sanctions. Left-leaning governments (Brazil, Mexico) criticize both Russia and NATO expansion. Right-leaning (Argentina) more aligned with West.

common_themes: Hypocrisy arguments - West ignored other conflicts
Economic hardship from sanctions and disrupted trade
Resentment at being forced to choose sides
Focus on negotiated settlement over military victory
Grain deal and food security as priority

verified_claims: UN General Assembly voted 141-5 condemning the invasion (March 2022)
Hundreds of thousands of casualties on both sides (exact numbers disputed)
Millions of Ukrainian refugees fled to Europe
Russian forces initially attempted to capture Kyiv but withdrew in April 2022
Russia annexed four Ukrainian regions (Donetsk, Luhansk, Zaporizhzhia, Kherson) in September 2022 - not internationally recognized
disputed_claims: Russian claim: Ukrainian government controlled by neo-Nazis (Ukrainian President Zelensky is Jewish)
Russian claim: NATO/US planned to use Ukraine to attack Russia
Ukrainian/Western claim: Russian forces deliberately target civilians
Casualty figures - both sides provide conflicting numbers

data_points.territory: Russia controls ~18% of Ukrainian territory (as of 2024)
data_points.economic_cost: World Bank estimates $411 billion in damages to Ukraine (as of 2023)

propaganda_techniques_observed: Whataboutism (citing US/NATO interventions in Kosovo, Iraq, etc.)
False equivalence (comparing Ukrainian nationalism to Nazism)

sources.description: Carnegie Endowment: Russia's Narratives on Ukraine
